description:
The Spring Framework is one of the most popular Java frameworks used today. While it is possible to use Spring in Scala, it does feel awkward in certain places, because of the "Javaism" peering through. For instance, using callback interfaces feels strange in Scala; functions would be a better match. In October 2012, I introduced the Spring Scala project, which solves this particular issue, and aims to make it easier to use Spring in Scala in general. In this session, we discuss the Spring Scala portfolio project and its feature set.

 


Arjen Poutsma
Arjen Poutsma is a Staff Engineer at SpringSource (a division of VMware) with more than fifteen years' experience in commercial software environments. During this time he has worked with both Java EE and Microsoft .NET.
In 2004, Arjen started to specialise in Web Services and Service Oriented Architectures. During this period he has conducted trainings and has researched SOAs in large organisations.
Arjen is the founder and the project lead for the Spring Web Services. This Spring project aims at facilitating development of document-driven web services. He worked on the REST support in Spring 3.0 and 3.1. Recently, Arjen started the Spring Scala project, aimed to make using Spring in Scala easier.
name: Using Spring in Scala with Arjen Poutsma

description:
Many in the group are starting to learn Scala and very often people have questions like: What is the most idiomatic way of writing that? Should I prefer pattern matching for Options or map/getOrElse?

 

The goal of this Scala Best Practices session is to discuss and share the best practices we are adopting on our projects and to create a space where beginners can bring and show their code and receive feedback from the community.

 

Location

We will meet at the cafetaria of the IT department (it goes by the name “the Foo Bar”). When you enter the hospital from the main entrance you have to follow the ‘bordeaux’ arrow-signs until the very end. From there you will find signs leading you to the right location.

Because of ongoing constructions some roads to reach the hospital are closed. Up-to-date information can be found at the UZ Leuven website:
http://www.uzleuven.be/node/12697

Practical

You can park your car in any of the visitor parkings. A free parking ticket will be provided during the event.

You can also reach the hospital by bus from the train station (nr 600 will take you straight to the hospital main entrance).

There’s a place to park bicycles near the main entrance.
name: Scala Best Practices

description:
Next to scala and the Play! framework, AKKA is the third offering from typesafe. It is also the least understood of the three. AKKA tries to ease the writing of concurrent, fault-tolerant and scalable applications on modern multicore hardware by offering the actor model abstraction.


This presentation gives an introduction of the actor model implemented in AKKA by explaining the concepts of actors, message passing, routers and supervisors. Small code samples will be shown to explain these concepts.

Speaker

Jan Van Sweevelt is a software engineer for almost twenty years, during this time he worked on many different types of projects from plantfoor systems to geographical information systems and was involved in the commercialization of internet and the WWW from the very beginning.
After becoming a consultant in 2005 he started to do more architect work in big enterprise projects and committing himself to better software engineering practices by applying agile principles in the teams he worked in.
In 2010 he discovered the AKKA framework and now tries to use it in every project that requires fault tolerance, scalable and high throughput.

This event is organized in cooperation with the Belgian Java User Group (www.bejug.org).

venue.name: KUL room C300 00.81 - Instituut voor Mechanica

how_to_find_us: KUL room C300 00.81 - Instituut voor Mechanica Celestijnenlaan 300, 3001 HEVERLEE
name: Introduction to Akka

description:
On this session we'll implement an application using Akka. We'll implement a 'map reduce' like search for geometric forms. 

Full use case explanation can be found here:

https://github.com/BeScala/bescala-hakking/

Please, make sure to check-out the code and play around with it before the event.

This BeScala meetup is generously hosted by AE in Leuven. 


We'll start at 6:00 PM with a sandwich buffet offered by AE. 

The hAkking session starts at 7:00 PM.
name: hAkking Session - Introduction to Akka follow up

description:
We are pleased to announce that our rendez-vous at Devoxx 2013 is confirmed.

Come and join us on Monday 11th November at 19:00 on the Scala Enthusiasts Gathering BoF for a informal meet-up with other Scala enthusiasts from Belgium and abroad.

The access to the BoFs are free of charge, but of course we strongly recommend a Devoxx subscription. As usual, Devoxx is featuring a lot of excellent talks.

Don’t wait till the last minute, get today your Devoxx subscription.
name: Scala Enthusiasts Gathering at Devoxx 2013

description: As agreed before and to respond the expectations of many in our community, we'll be meeting for a drink in center Brussel to discuss the Principles of Reactive Programming course.
name: Principles of Reactive Programming - study group

description:
Useful, of course! :) There’s even a Macros Paradise!

In the presentation, using some examples, I would like to show how and where macros are useful. We’ll start by live-coding a simple macro step-by-step. 

Then we’ll see some libraries, which use macros, to achieve things that were not possible before:

• MacWire, for framework-less dependency injection

• Slick, for direct embedding of case classes into database schemas

• Scala Async, for writing fully asynchronous code as if it was synchronous

Adam Warski

I am one of the co-founders of SoftwareMill, a company specialising in delivering customised software solutions. I code mostly using Scala and Java. I am involved in a number of open-source projects: as the founder and lead developer of Hibernate Envers, a Hibernate core module providing auditing capabilities, as well as the founder of ElasticMQ, Veripacks and MacWire. I have been a speaker at major conferences, such as Devoxx or Jazoon.

Apart from writing closed- and open-source software, I am interested in improving the way we use functional and object-oriented programming. When not coding, I enjoy spending time with my family, hiking in the mountains or playing tennis.

My blog: http://www.warski.org/blog

This event is generously hosted by Carambla and ParkOffice
name: Scala Macros - scary or useful?

description:
During this hacking session we are going to explore three different approaches to macro implementations

•  AST based approach

• reify/splice based approach

• quasiquotes based approach

and discuss their power of expression and conciseness.

Among others, we are going to implement some of the macros presented during the previous session (it is not necessary to have followed that session though).

The hacking session will be a moderated one: instead of working in isolation we are going to work together step-by-step on the same problems and sub-problems.

Be warned: the moderator is not a macro guru, but somebody who, just like you, tries to understand more about this interesting feature of the Scala programming language.

The hacking session will take place in a location with a limited amount of seats (approx. 10).

First booked, first served. If the hacking session turns out to be more successful than anticipated, then we can think of repeating it.
name: Scala Macros Hacking (with Luc Duponcheel)

description:
This talk will introduce Play'R, a recently open sourced project which helps quickly write coherent and introspectable ReST APIs in Play. 

Looking at the HTTP specification as a starting point, we will explore together the project's goals, functions and extensions. 

After that we will have a look at the project implementation, how it evolved and what we want to do in the future... with your help?

http://playr.26source.org/

Olivier Samyn

Olivier is a swiss army knife style engineer. From 80's Basic to Scala, he learned a good number of languages and acquired experience in various business sectors: university research, distribution, web agency, telecom, trading, hospital.

He is an open source enthusiast and works mainly with JVM based languages.

He is now developing web based applications for 26Lights, using AngularJS, Scala and PlayFramework.
name: Play'R - Playing with Play and ReST

description:
The goal of this hacking session is to brainstorm and implement a DSL for the routing in Play'R. 

We'll first have a 30 minutes hands-on to Play'R so everybody gets a good insight about the library. 

http://playr.26source.org/

https://github.com/26lights/PlayR 

Detailed program and hacking session project available at:

https://github.com/oleastre/PlayR-hack
name: Play'R Hacking

description:
Intro to Slick


Slick (part of the Typesafe stack) is a modern database query and access library for Scala, based on functional principles. It allows you to write queries as if you are working with regular Scala collections.

In this session we’ll have a deep dive into how you can use this library in real projects. How to map your tables and queries to structured objects, how to create more advanced queries with multiple joins, how to setup integration tests against an in-memory database and how you can integrate Slick with the Play Framework are all questions which will have been answered at the end of this session.


Slick in the field, learning to forget ORM


For many years developers on the JVM platform were used to ORM frameworks. Our code was filled with annotations (or worst XML configuration files). We learned how to map our classes to relational tables and deal with its peculiarities. We had big, sometimes huge graph of objects, mapped to relational tables. We brought them all to memory, changed them and let it be automagically persisted back at the end of our transactions.

In a Scala/Slick world we deal with data and persistence in a totally different way. Our model are immutable structures (case classes and tuples), nullable columns are mapped to Options (and that's cool), relations are expressed by id references instead of object associations (that's less cool). Instead of writing xml or filling our code with annotations, we write type-safe idiomatic Scala code. We compose queries in a functional style. We map and flatMap over it.

But is that good or bad? What brings Slick to the readability and maintainability of our code base? How do we test our business logic when a great deal of it is executed outside the JVM?

In this talk we'll share our experience in building real world applications with Slick. The lessons learned, the patterns and anti-patterns we went through in our journey to shift the way we were used to think about persistence.

Yennick Trevels (Intro to Slick)
Yennick is currently a Reactive Applications Developer and certified Typesafe trainer at Xplore Group, where he’s actively working with Scala, Slick and Play.
Before he started working with Scala and the Typesafe stack he had six years of experience in enterprise software development with Java and Flex. During his career, he has always been investigating best-practices and ways to broaden his development toolbox.
He is also the co-founder and project lead of the GradleFx open source project, a Gradle plugin to build Flex applications.

Site: yennicktrevels.com
Twitter: @SlevinBE

Renato Cavalcanti (Slick in the Field)

Renato Cavalcanti is an independent Scala developer based in Belgium. Coming from a totally different field (psychology), he discovered a passion for programming in 1999. Scala aficionado since 2007, he has been hacking in Scala and related technologies for fun and profit. He's the founder of BeScala and steering committee member of the BeJUG.


Site: strongtyped.io
Twitter: @renatocaval
name: Intro to Slick / Slick in the Field

description:
Scala.js

Scala.js allows you to use Scala to write applications for the browser. We will build a little example application that shows the development setup and how to use JavaScript libraries such as jQuery from Scala. We will examine how to test the code and how to call Scala functions from JavaScript.

Lutz Huehnken


Lutz Huehnken is a Trainer and Consultant at Typesafe. He has worked in professional software development since 1997, and has successfully deployed major web applications for clients in different fields (retail, logistics, hospitality, finance). After 15 years of Java development, Lutz has made the switch to Scala in 2012 and has made it his ongoing task to help others to do the same.
name: Scala.js

description:
So, here we go!

As previously announced on the mailing list we'll be running a series of hacking sessions for Scala novices. 

We follow the book Atomic Scala and use the its Activator Template for the exercises. 

The first 100 pages of the book can be downloaded for free on their website.
http://www.atomicscala.com/


The corresponding Activator Template is available on the template repository. Are you new to Activator? Check it out here to find out how it works. 

Don't hesitate to drop a message on our mailing list if you have any trouble in installing and using Activator.

And remember, we'll start from scratch, but more seasoned Scala devs are much welcome. Any help in assisting our fellow BeScalians is welcome. And you can be sure that by helping others you'll also discover new tricks about Scala.
name: Atomic Scala - hacking sessions

description:
Rapture is a collection of libraries for everyday programming tasks like I/O, JSON & XML processing and cryptography, with a focus on beautiful, concise and intuitive code. Rapture packs a lot of power into a single line of code, and Jon will race through fifty of Rapture's smartest one-liners at a rate of one-a-minute, showing you how easy it is to perform everyday file and network I/O and structured data operations, without compromising type safety. All the code in the talk will be easy for beginners to understand, but more advanced developers may also learn some new tricks, so there should be something for everyone!

Jon Pretty

Jon has been involved in the Scala community for the last ten years, having launched the first commercial and open-source Scala software back in 2005. Since then, he has successfully deployed Scala projects into small, medium and large businesses, and UK government, but is best known these days for his work on Rapture, and more recently Typelevel Scala.
name: Rapture: The Art of the One-Liner

description:
We are pleased to announce that our rendez-vous at Devoxx 2014 is confirmed.

The access to the BoFs are free of charge, but of course we strongly recommend a Devoxx subscription. Hurry up because it's almost sold-out! 

BoF's abstract


The Scala meetup at Devoxx where Scala users and fans get together to socialize and discuss all things about Scala.

Scala popularity, its ecosystem and its community are growing each year. 2014 has been a wonderful year in this regard.

2014 is the year we commemorate the 10 years of Scala, but also the 5 years of Akka. It's the year of the Reactive Streams initiative and the emerging of Spark and stream processing as the next big thing in Big Data. And it's also the year of the Typelevel Scala fork.

It's also the year of Java 8 where our fellow colleagues are discovering the delightfulness of functional programming.

That and much more only make our community as vibrant as ever and the Scala Meetup at Devoxx is the place to be for everyone involved or willing to get involved with Scala.
name: BeScala Meetup @ Devoxx
